header.title: The Llewellyn Practical Guide to The Development of Psychic Powers
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Psychic Development, Practical Magic

central_thesis: The book's central thesis is that psychic abilities are a natural and fundamental part of every human being's heritage, not exclusive to a select few, and can be developed through a structured, holistic program that integrates physical well-being, mental attitude, and specific meditative and interactive exercises. It emphasizes accessing the deeper, unconscious levels of the psyche and understanding its inherent connection to the 'astral world' as the foundation for these powers.

structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces psychic development as a 'natural development' and encourages a 'play' attitude. It highlights the interrelationship between the body and psyche, advocating for a healthy lifestyle (diet, rest, aerobic exercise) and the daily practice of the 'Tabor Formulation' meditation. Practical instructions are provided for making essential psychic equipment like a pendulum, ESP cards, and a Vision Mirror, along with keeping a 'log-book' for progress.

This section emphasizes the importance of mental attitude in psychic development, advising against boredom, stress, and prolonged mental concentration. It suggests cultivating 'imaginative enthusiasm' and engaging with the 'natural world' and 'human world' to foster psychic relatedness. Initial tests using ESP cards are detailed for group and individual telepathy/prediction, alongside pendulum use for telekinesis and divination. The 'Mind Painting' game is introduced as a fun way to project and perceive imagined shapes, and the concept of 'time-slip' in test results for foreknowledge is discussed.

This chapter delves into the human psyche, defining it as a 'non-material self' with entry into the Collective Unconscious and various life forces. It outlines the four main levels of function: Spirit (Higher Self), Mental (conscious rational mind), Astral (emotional and instinctual, origin of psychic powers), and Physical Body. The 'Reflection on the Psycho-physical Unity' meditation is presented as a vital process to strengthen the interaction between these levels. Historical experiments demonstrating telekinesis and telepathy are discussed, explaining the roles of 'astral substance' and 'aura'. The 'Guessing Dice' game is provided as a means to develop telekinetic ability.

This part explores the sources of foreknowledge, distinguishing between 'Divination' (communication with the Divine Mind) and 'Seership' (seeing into the Causal World or Astral World). It acknowledges that foreknowledge can stem from multiple sources including the Higher Self, telepathy from others' unconscious minds, instinct, auric vibration, and the Collective Unconscious. The chapter emphasizes meditation and a harmonious life-attitude for developing prophetic faculties. It introduces the 'Call-in' game using ESP cards for prediction and telepathy, and provides a two-stage practice for scrying with the Vision Mirror, including a group scrying game.

This chapter introduces 'Psychometry' as the psychic ability to sense circumstances or impressions associated with material objects through touch. It explains that all objects have an 'astral level' susceptible to impressions, particularly those imbued by human emotional force or historical events. The process involves calm relaxation and passively receiving material from the object's astral vibrations, likened to 'dreaming awake'. Pointers for practice include working alone with a tape recorder, using varied items, and progressing to group psychometry with verifiable objects.

This section explores the spiritualist path of gaining help from 'discarnate' beings. It describes how to conduct a spiritualist 'sitting' or 'circle', emphasizing the opening with the Tabor Formulation and an invocation. It details the nature of 'Trance' (light to deep) and the role of 'Guides' as protectors and advisors. Methods for generating energy in the circle are outlined, including linking hands, burning incense, using music/song, and red light. The importance of exercising authority in the circle and returning to normal consciousness after the session is stressed. The chapter encourages personal decision regarding this path and suggests visiting professional mediums to attune to spiritualist procedures.

This chapter focuses on dowsing as a natural, inborn psychic ability operating at the emotional-instinctual (astral) level. It clarifies that dowsing responds to the 'astral counterpart' of objects (present, past, or future impressions, termed 'remanence'). The text debunks the 'unconscious muscular movement' theory, asserting that dowsing movement is a form of telekinesis directed by the unconscious mind. Various dowsing instruments (angle-rods, cane/rattan loop, dowsing fork, single wand) are described with instructions for making and using them. The process of 'self-programming' with a 'directive' (token or map) to establish affinity with the search object is detailed, along with games ('Magnets', 'Hot Trail', 'Whose?', 'Whose Name?') to develop dowsing sensitivities.

key_concepts.definition: A state in which a person is to some extent withdrawn from normal awareness of the material world. Some altered states are so slight as to be accepted without notice, others are easily recognized as one or another degree of trance.

Archetype: A universal image/essential concept existing within the collective unconscious mind of humanity. Archetypal Image: The form in which an archetype is clothed by a particular culture, mythology, religion or individual.

Pertaining to that level of existence which is finer and more penetrating than matter but denser than mind. It is the emotional/instinctual level of the psyche, which unites mind and body and is the origin of psychic powers.
An emanation of energy given out by, and forming a force-field surrounding, a living being. It acts as a transmitting and receiving instrument in telepathy and a receptor for data.
The astral level of an animate or inanimate material object. The counterpart can persist after the material object, as such, has ceased to exist.
A sample or representative of what is sought, used as an aid in dowsing (sometimes called a 'Witness' in pendulum dowsing).
Without a physical body. Discarnate beings can have become separated from their physical bodies (e.g., human souls after death) or may never have had earthly bodies (e.g., archangels, elementals).
Discovery of the future or of the unknown, usually by a specific technique rather than spontaneously.

A method for seeking out material objects, and living beings, usually with the use of a 'fork' or other instrument. It is an inborn psychic ability operating at the emotional-instinctual (astral) level of the psyche.
A 'nature-spirit', one of the living beings of the Astral World; less individuated than human beings, subrational, highly sensitive, emotional and imitative.

A word of Greek origin, which initially meant 'inspiration or possession by a god'; in this context, an emotional interest which can lead to total absorption of attention in a subject and hence to some degree of 'altered state of consciousness'.

Generally-used abbreviation for 'extra-sensory perception', that is, the gain of awareness without using the physical senses. Pure ESP is a gain of awareness directly from the subject-matter, not taking it by telepathy from the mind of another.

In testing with a standard-plan deck of ESP cards, the average of right answers which can be expected from a 'randomed' machine or a person of no psychic ability is termed 'hazard level': in practice this is 20% (5 correct in 25). Both higher than hazard and lower than hazard averages are significant.
A state between sleep and wakefulness, which can tend in either direction. In this state, the consciousness becomes intermittently invaded by images and impulses from the unconscious.
An innate, sub-rational and usually unconscious impulse, prompting living beings to act in given ways in certain situations which are critical in their lives.
A word, phrase or sentence repeated during devotion or meditation.
(In Spiritualism). A person who becomes an intermediary by providing the spirits with means of communicating with the incarnate.
A declaration of something which is in the future or otherwise ordinarily unknown. The word is often reserved to instances in which the seer obtains knowledge by contact with the Divine.
The non-material part of a psycho-physical being. It is a far vaster reality than conscious 'I' and has access to the Collective Unconscious of humanity and all life forces.
Movements caused in an object by psychic (that is, astral) means. Also known as Psychokinesis.
The faculty of gaining knowledge about an object, or about any matter associated with it, by handling the object.
(In Dowsing) Occurrence of reactions relating to a bygone material object or condition, as if the object or condition were still present. It can also refer to 'the shape of things to come'.
Divination by allowing the eyes to rest on a plain surface so that the mind becomes stilled, and receptive to imagery which arises from the Unconscious.

Higher Self: That part of the psyche which is more elevated than the rational consciousness; the spirit. Lower Self: The rational consciousness with the emotional/instinctual nature and the physical body.
(1) The highest level of the psyche. (2) an elemental, or other being which is disembodied by nature. (3) In Spiritualism, a disembodied human soul.
Literally 'below the threshold'; here applied to experience or knowledge which enters the psyche, and can even result in action, without itself coming to consciousness.
An 'altered state of consciousness', especially the more withdrawn degrees resembling sleep or sleepwalking. A light trance state is conducive to receiving non-material influences.
To form a mental image. The important factor for success in this is the knowledge that the image is to be mental, not an optical illusion. It can however seem to be optically visible.

practical_system.description: The book outlines a comprehensive, progressive system for developing psychic powers by focusing on the 'astral level' of the psyche. It stresses a holistic approach, integrating physical well-being (diet, rest, aerobic exercise), mental attitude ('imaginative enthusiasm', 'play' spirit, 'letting-go' principle), and specific meditative techniques. The system encourages both individual and group practice, framed around various 'games' and exercises designed to awaken and refine different psychic faculties. The authors provide clear, actionable steps for each practice, emphasizing patient, consistent application and meticulous record-keeping to track progress and identify personal aptitudes. The underlying philosophy positions psychic abilities as inherent human potential, accessible through conscious effort and understanding of the subtle interactions between the self and the 'astral world'.
tools: Pendulum (preferably turned wood, or ring-shaped, with a basal point for spherical/cylindrical types).
ESP Cards (a deck of 25 cards with 5 distinct symbols, e.g., star, circle, square, cross, wavy lines).
Vision Mirror (a concave disc, ~8 inches across, with a black gloss 'mirror' surface, housed in a rigid structure).
Log-book / Diary (for recording dates, participants, activities, results, observations, and environmental factors like Moon Phase and Weather).
Card-holder (for ESP card testing, a double-thickness cardboard stand with a recess to hold cards).
Angle-rods (two L-shaped wires, ~15 inches long with 5-inch handles, free to rotate within sleeves).
Cane or Rattan Loop (a flexible loop of plant stem, ~27 inches long, bound securely).
Dowsing Fork (a Y-shaped branch of hazel, willow, or fruit-wood, ~10 inches long, prongs ~5-8 inches, with sealed ends).
Single Wand (a long, straight, slender, flexible rod of wood, metal, or synthetic material).
Directive / Witness (a small sample or token representing the object of search for dowsing, e.g., water sample, mineral chip, plant leaves, photograph, map, or written name).
Timer (for setting time limits in ESP tests).
Bell or Electric Sound-signal (for signaling new cards in ESP tests).
Tape Recorder (for recording verbalized impressions during psychometry sessions).
Incense (joss-sticks or cones, e.g., sandalwood, patchouli, for energy arousal in spiritualist sittings).
Music/Song (for establishing harmonious atmosphere and energy arousal in spiritualist sittings).
Red Light (for stimulating energy and aiding 'astral sight' in spiritualist sittings).
Negative Ionizer (suggested as an optional aid for improving general well-being and potentially enhancing psychic tests).
rituals: Tabor Formulation: Daily meditation involving comfortable posture, deep breathing, awareness of golden light (love) between navel and chin, and silent utterance of mantrams affirming oneness with the Cosmos.

Reflection on the Psycho-physical Unity: A weekly meditative process to strengthen the interaction between the four levels of the psyche (Spirit, Mental, Astral, Physical Body), contemplating one's relationship with the material world/body, emotional/instinctual self, mental self, and Higher Self.

ESP Card Testing: Individual or group tests using Zener cards (star, circle, square, cross, wavy lines) to develop telepathy and prediction, including 'cards unseen' and 'prediction tests', and the 'Call-in' game for group telepathy/prediction.

Pendulum Telekinesis Testing: Using a pendulum suspended from a frame, visualizing its movement to make it swing in a specific direction without physical contact, then stopping or changing its direction.
Pendulum Divination Testing: Holding a pendulum from fingers to answer yes/no questions, establishing a clear 'yes' (forward-back) and 'no' (side-to-side) code, for group or individual use.
'Mind Painting' Game: A group exercise in projecting and perceiving imagined shapes onto a dark surface (blackboard/screen), with participants scoring points for accurate projection and reception.

Psychometry Practice: Holding a material object (preferably wrapped), entering a state of calm relaxation, passively receiving emotional or historical impressions from its 'astral level', and verbalizing these impressions, preferably recorded.

Spiritualist Circle Sittings: Opening with Tabor Formulation, aspiration and invocation by a leader, linking hands to raise energy, using incense, music/song, and red light to induce light trance for communication with discarnate beings (Guides/Controls).

Dowsing Practice: Preparing a 'directive' (sample or token of the sought object), 'self-programming' by focusing emotions and imagination on the object, 'talking' to the dowsing instrument to create affinity, and walking outdoors to receive signals (movements) from the instrument based on astral counterparts.

'Magnets' Game: A group 'astral power game' where one blindfolded 'pin' stands in the center, and others ('magnets') silently influence the 'pin' to lean towards a chosen 'magnet' without physical contact, to simulate dowsing sensation.

'Hot Trail' Game: A group ESP game where one player leaves the room, others choose and touch an object to 'charge' it, and the returning player uses fingertip sensitivity to identify the 'charged' object.

'Whose?' and 'Whose Name?' Pendulum Games: Group games for dowsing competence. 'Whose?' involves guessing the owner of a concealed object using a pendulum. 'Whose Name?' involves dowsing to match slips of paper with names to individuals without the operator knowing the name or owner beforehand.

relevant_quotes.text: "This book says that psychic abilities are natural to everyone! They are not merely fantasy, but real and a dynamic part of your total mind/body/soul/spirit whole being that should not be neglected."

"Remember - your psychic powers are a natural part of your life as a human being. You are not trying to graft anything on from the outside; you are not like a horse pulling a cart, but more like a bird learning to fly: it's a natural expression of your growth into a more whole person."
"DON'T OVER-TEST: HAVE FUN! As a researcher - FOLLOW THE EVIDENCE WHEREVER IT LEADS!"
"The psychic powers have their foundation in the astral level of the psyche."
"THIS MOVEMENT IS PRODUCED BY A FORM OF TELEKINESIS: TELEKINESIS DIRECTED BY THE UNCONSCIOUS MIND OF THE OPERATOR AND NOT, AS IN THE CASE OF ORDINARY TELEKINESIS, BY THE CONSCIOUS MIND."

critical_analysis.relevance: This guide by Denning & Phillips offers a highly relevant and accessible approach to psychic development, grounding it in the natural capabilities of the human psyche rather than presenting it as a purely 'supernatural' or rare gift. Their background in the Hermetic Ogdoadic Tradition provides a structured, albeit demystified, framework. The emphasis on practical, 'game-like' exercises and a holistic lifestyle (diet, rest, aerobic exercise, meditation) makes the development process engaging and integrated with overall well-being. By linking psychic abilities to the 'astral level' of the psyche and advocating for 'imaginative enthusiasm' and 'letting-go', the authors provide a system that is both technically coherent within esoteric thought and psychologically sound for practical application. It demystifies often-feared concepts like astral substance and mediumship, presenting them as aspects of a deeper, accessible reality.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for this book is primarily beginners and aspiring practitioners of psychic development and practical magic, as well as those with intermediate experience seeking a structured, self-directed or group-based system. It caters to individuals interested in a non-dogmatic, holistic approach that integrates physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual growth with the development of specific psychic faculties such as ESP, telekinesis, divination, psychometry, and dowsing. It would also appeal to readers interested in Western Esotericism who appreciate a practical, 'hands-on' guide over purely theoretical texts, especially those familiar with Llewellyn's broader range of occult publications.
